title: PE Daily: Leonard Green Preps Fundraising Push | Oppenheimer Faces Southport Backlash
text:
Meanwhile, Chris Cumming continues to report on the fallout from a recent Securities & Exchange action alleging that an employee of Southport Capital ran a ponzi scheme. This time, a group of investors are suing Oppenheimer & Co. Inc., claiming that the investment bank is also at fault.

Dive in for more details on these stories and many others...

Today's Top Stories

Leonard Green & Partners, which owns companies that include retailers Jo-Ann Stores LLC and 1-800 Contacts, is gearing up for its next big fundraising pitch less than two years after it closed its predecessor fund, Preeti Singh writes for WSJ Pro Private Equity. The Los Angeles-based firm has informed several investors that it plans to open a virtual online data room for its next fundraising effort sometime after Labor Day, which falls on Sept. 6 this year, according to people familiar with the matter. Prospective investors will be able to review documents about the new fund, these people said.

A class-action lawsuit claims investment bank Oppenheimer & Co. Inc. was at fault for an alleged Ponzi scheme run by a former employee, which authorities say collected $110 million from unwitting investors, Chris Cumming reports for WSJ Pro Private Equity. A suit filed Tuesday in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia in Atlanta alleges that from 2008 through 2016, a group of former Oppenheimer investment advisers, led by Marietta, Ga., resident John J. Woods, funneled the money of Oppenheimer customers into a fraudulent scheme.

Big Number

$108 Billion

Total spending on global merger and acquisitions in the technology sector in August, according to research provider S&P Global Market Intelligence's 451 Research. In August, 22 deals involving technology companies topped $1 billion, according to the data.

Deals

Children sit in a classroom. Photo: Nicolas Lambert, Belga via Zuma Press

Technology focused Francisco Partners is buying Follett School Solutions, a software and content unit of Follett Corporation that serves grades K-12. The business will become part of Francisco's growing portfolio of educational technologies and businesses focused on the K-12 market, according to a press release.

Leonard Green & Partners has made a minority investment in Tecta America Corporation, a commercial roofing company backed by fellow private-equity investor Altas Partners. Altas, which initially backed Tecta in 2018, will remain a majority shareholder in the company.

LKCM Headwater Investments, the private equity arm of registered investment adviser Luther King Capital Management, has led a $200 million series A investment round for ProbablyMonsters Inc., a video gaming development company based in Bellevue, Wash.

GHO Capital Partners, a European private-equity firm focused on healthcare, has acquired a majority stake in healthcare-focused strategic consulting firm Clearview Healthcare Partners from RLH Equity Partners and the company's management.

Oaktree Capital Management and unnamed institutional investors are investing $250 million in private-equity backed Priority Power Management LLC, an Arlington, Texas-based energy services provider. Houston-based Ara Partners acquired Priority Power in 2019 and will retain an ownership stake, according to a press release.

Lee Equity Partners, a private-equity firm in New York that backs midmarket companies, bought a stake in Pure Financial Advisors Inc. Founded in 2007, San Diego-backed Pure is a registered investment advisor with $3.6 billion in assets, according to a news release.

Midmarket firm Centre Partners said it has recapitalized Midwest Mobility Solutions, a Troy, Michigan-based authorized retailer for AT&T. Midwest Mobility's co-founders Matt Sharrak and Nash Khami will retain a significant stake in the business, according to a press release.

Motive Partners has led a $100 million series B growth funding round for Insurify, a technology company that allows users to shop for insurance and compare different insurance products. Other investors in the round include existing investors Viola FinTech, MassMutual Ventures, Nationwide, Hearst Ventures, Moneta VC, as well as new investors Viola Growth and Fort Ross Ventures, according to a press release.

Vista Equity Partners has agreed to make a strategic growth investment in Drift, a business-to-business sales and marketing enterprise technology company.

Northstar Capital, a provider of junior capital for midmarket companies, said it has invested in Minnesota-based Consolidated Equipment Group, LLC, a portfolio company of midmarket firm Dominus Capital.

Exits

Consumer focused L Catterton has sold the recreational vehicle parts unit of portfolio company AirX Intermediate, Inc. to Thor Industries Inc. for $750 million, Colin Kellaher writes for Dow Jones Newswires. L Catterton originally acquired the company, known as Airxcel, in 2018. The firm retains Airxcel's specialty heating, ventilation and air-conditioning business, which it renamed AirX Climate Solutions Inc.

Automaker Stellantis NV agreed to buy U.S. auto finance firm First Investors Financial Services Group for about $285 million in an all-cash transaction, expanding the range of financing options it gives to customers and dealers, Kimberly Chin writes for Dow Jones Newswires. The company will acquire F1 Holdings Corp., the parent company of First Investors, from an investor group led by private-equity firm Gallatin Point Capital LLC and that includes affiliates of financial services-focused Jacobs Asset Management LLC.

Growth investment firm Edison Partners said it is selling its stake in legal technology company Bodhala Inc. to Onit Inc., the firm's third exit to a strategic buyer in the past two months. Edison initially invested in New York-based Bodhala in April 2020, the firm said in the press release.

FAT Brands Inc. said Wednesday it agreed to pay $300 million to buy Twin Peaks, a Dallas-based chain of more than 100 sports lodges offering cold draft beer, from New York-based private-equity firm Garnett Station Partners LLC, Steve Gelsi writes for sister publication MarketWatch.

Chicago-based impact investment firm Maxim Partners said it has agreed to sell pet product brand Zesty Paws to Health & Happiness Group for $610 million. Maxim initially acquired Zesty Paws in 2018.

The HAVI Group LP said it has acquired Pacific Market International, LLC, or PMI Worldwide, a producer of sustainable packaging backed by midmarket firm Endeavour Capital.

Artemis Capital Partners, a Boston-based private-equity firm focused on industrial technology deals, has sold industrial machine and tool manufacturer Ohio Tool Works LLC to machine tool company Hardinge Inc. Artemis recapitalized Ohio Tool Works in 2013.

Funds

AGIC Capital, a European and Asian firm that targets investments in industrial and technology deals, has rounded up $1.2 billion for its second fund AGIC Capital II LP. The firm typically takes majority and minority stakes in companies with enterprise values of $50 million to $500 million, according to a press release.

Dayone Capital has rounded up $630 million for its first U.S. dollar-denominated fund, Dayone Capital Fund I to back Chinese consumer facing companies across multiple investment stages. The fund has already backed 10 companies, according to a press release. They include Chinese designer toy brand PopMart, tea shop chain Heytea and electric vehicle manufacturer Li Auto, among others. Dayone Capital was founded by Chinese entrepreneur Allen Chen.

People

Midmarket focused RCP Advisors has hired Mary Hunt as a principal and portfolio manager for the firm's diversity, equity and inclusion strategy, the firm said in an emailed press release. Ms. Hunt joins Chicago-based RCP from Allstate Investments, where she was head of portfolio management and analytics and also served as a principal in the company's private-equity group.

Il Makiage, a beauty brand backed by private-equity firm L Catterton, named Lindsay Drucker Mann as its first global chief financial officer. Ms. Drucker Mann previously worked for 17 years at Goldman Sachs Inc., where she was most recently a managing director and head of technology and consumer equity capital markets, according to a news release.

Industry News

CVC Capital Partners will return to Australia after a nine year absence, rebuilding its presence in what it called one of the most active private-equity markets in Asia-Pacific, Stuart Condie writes for Dow Jones Newswires. CVC, which has US$115 billion in assets under management and 24 offices globally, said it would open a Sydney office under Brett Sutton. Mr. Sutton, who founded Affinity Partners' Australian operations in 2004, has joined CVC as chair of Australia to oversee the expansion.

Facing pressure from investors to show progress on diversity issues, more companies are publicizing workforce representation data they already report confidentially to the U.S. government, Dieter Holger writes for WSJ Pro Sustainable Business. Since 1966, private companies with 100 or more employees have to disclose to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission how many men and women of different ethnicities they employ across 10 job categories, such as "laborers and helpers," "professionals" and "executive/senior level officials." Aggregated data on industries and major geographic areas are published by the government, without company-specific information.
